security_audit.summary: Pure prompt-based skill with no executable code. Only contains documentation and workflow guidance for claim validation. MCP tool references are standard Claude Code capabilities.

content.user_title: Verify claims and block false progress reports
content.value_statement: AI agents sometimes report success prematurely. This skill validates every claim against actual codebase state, runs actual builds and tests, and blocks progress when issues are detected.
actual_capabilities: Validates all claims against actual codebase state
Runs actual build commands to verify status
Parses test files to confirm real tests exist
Detects false positives like stub tests or hidden build errors
Blocks progress when blockers are found
Integrates with Orchestrator to route issues to Diagnostics Agent
limitations: Does not fix issues, only identifies them
Cannot access external APIs or services beyond Claude Code MCP tools
Requires MCP tools (Playwright, Filesystem, Git, Bash) to be available
Cannot validate claims in systems outside the codebase

use_cases.title: Prevent false completion reports
use_cases.description: Catch false positives before they cause deployment failures or missed deadlines

use_cases.title: Verify build and test status
use_cases.description: Run actual build commands instead of trusting status indicators

use_cases.title: Detect stub tests and fake coverage
use_cases.description: Parse test files to verify tests are real, not empty stubs

prompt_templates.title: Basic claim validation
prompt_templates.prompt: Use Truth Layer to verify: The team claims the build is successful. Run the actual build command and report what you find.

prompt_templates.title: Test coverage check
prompt_templates.prompt: Truth Layer, check if our test coverage claim is accurate. Parse the test files and count real tests vs stubs.

prompt_templates.title: Type safety verification
prompt_templates.prompt: Run typecheck and report any errors. Block progress if type errors exist anywhere in the chain.

prompt_templates.title: Full verification workflow
prompt_templates.prompt: Truth Layer, perform complete verification: check build status, validate tests, run typecheck, inspect file integrity. Report all blockers.

output_examples.input: Verify if the feature is complete and ready for deployment
output: CLAIM: Feature is complete and ready
REALITY: Build fails with type errors
ACTION REQUIRED: Fix type errors and install missing dependency before proceeding

best_practices: Run Truth Layer before every major milestone report
Always let Truth Layer block progress when issues are found
Route blockers to Diagnostics Agent for root cause analysis
anti_patterns: Trusting build status without running actual build commands
Counting stub test files as real test coverage
Ignoring build warnings that hide actual failures

faq.question: What tools does Truth Layer use?
faq.answer: It uses Claude Code MCP tools: Playwright for UI inspection, Filesystem for file integrity, Git for history, and Bash for build commands.

faq.question: Can Truth Layer fix the issues it finds?
faq.answer: No, Truth Layer only identifies and reports blockers. It routes issues to the Diagnostics Agent for root cause analysis.

faq.question: Does Truth Layer work with all programming languages?
faq.answer: Yes, it validates claims regardless of language by running actual build commands and checking file states.

faq.question: Is my data safe with Truth Layer?
faq.answer: Yes, Truth Layer runs locally within Claude Code and only accesses your codebase. No data leaves your environment.

faq.question: Why does my build show success but Truth Layer reports failure?
faq.answer: Truth Layer runs actual build commands and checks for hidden errors like Turbopack warnings that may indicate the artifact is broken.

faq.question: How is Truth Layer different from a linter?
faq.answer: Truth Layer validates claims about project state, not code quality. It confirms that what is claimed is actually true in the running system.
